sentence.text: Drug Label for drug brand DIURIL, containing CHLOROTHIAZIDE.

mmtx.phraseText: Drug Label for drug brand DIURIL,
Drug Label for drug brand DIURIL,

sentence.text: Thiazides may add to or potentiate the action of other antihypertensive drugs.

entity.text: add to or potentiate the action

mmtx.phraseText: the action of other antihypertensive drugs.

sentence.text: Lithium generally should not be given with diuretics (see PRECAUTIONS, Drug Interactions).
All patients receiving diuretic therapy should be observed for evidence of fluid or electrolyte imbalance: namely, hyponatremia, hypochloremic alkalosis, and hypokalemia.
Hypokalemia may be avoided or treated by use of potassium-sparing diuretics or potassium supplements such as foods with a high potassium content.

mmtx.phraseText: treated by use of potassium-sparing diuretics

sentence.text: In diabetic patients dosage adjustments of insulin or oral hypoglycemic agents may be required.

ellipsisSentence.text: Hyperuricemia may occur or acute gout may be precipitated in certain patients receiving thiazides.

sentence.text: Thiazides may decrease urinary calcium excretion.
Thiazides may cause intermittent and slight elevation of serum calcium in the absence of known disorders of calcium metabolism.
Periodic determination of serum electrolytes to detect possible electrolyte imbalance should be done at appropriate intervals.

mmtx.phraseText: Periodic determination of serum electrolytes to

sentence.text: Alcohol, barbiturates, or narcotics - potentiation of orthostatic hypotension may occur.

ellipsisSentence.text: When given concurrently the following drugs may interact with thiazide diuretics.

sentence.text: Antidiabetic drugs (oral agents and insulin) - dosage adjustment of the antidiabetic drug may be required.

ellipsisSentence.text: When given concurrently the following drugs may interact with thiazide diuretics.

middleSentence.text: Alcohol, barbiturates, or narcotics - potentiation of orthostatic hypotension may occur.

sentence.text: Cholestyramine and colestipol resins - Both cholestyramine and colestipol resins have the potential of binding thiazide diuretics and reducing diuretic absorption from the gastrointestinal tract.

mmtx.phraseText: the potential of binding thiazide diuretics

sentence.text: Corticosteroids, ACTH - intensified electrolyte depletion, particularly hypokalemia.

ellipsisSentence.text: When given concurrently the following drugs may interact with thiazide diuretics.

middleSentence.text: Alcohol, barbiturates, or narcotics - potentiation of orthostatic hypotension may occur.
Antidiabetic drugs (oral agents and insulin) - dosage adjustment of the antidiabetic drug may be required.
Other antihypertensive drugs - additive effect or potentiation.
Cholestyramine and colestipol resins - Both cholestyramine and colestipol resins have the potential of binding thiazide diuretics and reducing diuretic absorption from the gastrointestinal tract.

ellipsisSentence.text: When given concurrently the following drugs may interact with thiazide diuretics.

middleSentence.text: Alcohol, barbiturates, or narcotics - potentiation of orthostatic hypotension may occur.
Antidiabetic drugs (oral agents and insulin) - dosage adjustment of the antidiabetic drug may be required.
Other antihypertensive drugs - additive effect or potentiation.
Cholestyramine and colestipol resins - Both cholestyramine and colestipol resins have the potential of binding thiazide diuretics and reducing diuretic absorption from the gastrointestinal tract.

sentence.text: Pressor amines (e.g., norepinephrine) - possible decreased response to pressor amines but not sufficient to preclude their use.

mmtx.phraseText: possible decreased response to pressor amines

ellipsisSentence.text: When given concurrently the following drugs may interact with thiazide diuretics.

middleSentence.text: Alcohol, barbiturates, or narcotics - potentiation of orthostatic hypotension may occur.
Antidiabetic drugs (oral agents and insulin) - dosage adjustment of the antidiabetic drug may be required.
Other antihypertensive drugs - additive effect or potentiation.
Cholestyramine and colestipol resins - Both cholestyramine and colestipol resins have the potential of binding thiazide diuretics and reducing diuretic absorption from the gastrointestinal tract.
Corticosteroids, ACTH - intensified electrolyte depletion, particularly hypokalemia.

sentence.text: Skeletal muscle relaxants, nondepolarizing (e.g., tubocurarine) - possible increased responsiveness to the muscle relaxant.

ellipsisSentence.text: When given concurrently the following drugs may interact with thiazide diuretics.

middleSentence.text: Alcohol, barbiturates, or narcotics - potentiation of orthostatic hypotension may occur.
Antidiabetic drugs (oral agents and insulin) - dosage adjustment of the antidiabetic drug may be required.
Other antihypertensive drugs - additive effect or potentiation.
Cholestyramine and colestipol resins - Both cholestyramine and colestipol resins have the potential of binding thiazide diuretics and reducing diuretic absorption from the gastrointestinal tract.
Corticosteroids, ACTH - intensified electrolyte depletion, particularly hypokalemia.
Pressor amines (e.g., norepinephrine) - possible decreased response to pressor amines but not sufficient to preclude their use.

sentence.text: Lithium - generally should not be given with diuretics.
Diuretic agents reduce the renal clearance of lithium and add a high risk of lithium toxicity.

mmtx.phraseText: a high risk of lithium toxicity.

sentence.text: Refer to the package insert for lithium preparations before use of such preparations with DIURIL.

Non-steroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs Including Selective Cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) Inhibitors - In some patients, the administration of a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agent including a selective COX-2 inhibitor can reduce the diuretic, natriuretic, and antihypertensive effects of loop, potassium-sparing and thiazide diuretics.

mmtx.phraseText: the administration of a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agent
the administration of a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agent

sentence.text: Therefore, when DIURIL and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents or selective COX-2 inhibitors are used concomitantly, the patient should be observed closely to determine if the desired effect of the diuretic is obtained.

In some patients with compromised renal function (e.g., elderly patients or patients who are volume-depleted, including those on diuretic therapy) who are being treated with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, including selective COX-2 inhibitors, the co-administration of angiotensin II receptor antagonists or ACE inhibitors may result in a further deterioration of renal function, including possible acute renal failure.

mmtx.phraseText: the co-administration of angiotensin II receptor antagonists

sentence.text: These interactions should be considered in patients taking NSAIDs including selective COX-2 inhibitors concomitantly with diuretics and angiotensin II antagonists or ACE inhibitors.

mmtx.phraseText: selective COX-2 inhibitors concomitantly with diuretics
selective COX-2 inhibitors concomitantly with diuretics

sentence.text: Therefore, the combination should be administered with caution, especially in the elderly.

ellipsisSentence.text: These interactions should be considered in patients taking NSAIDs including selective COX-2 inhibitors concomitantly with diuretics and angiotensin II antagonists or ACE inhibitors.
These interactions should be considered in patients taking NSAIDs including selective COX-2 inhibitors concomitantly with diuretics and angiotensin II antagonists or ACE inhibitors.
These interactions should be considered in patients taking NSAIDs including selective COX-2 inhibitors concomitantly with diuretics and angiotensin II antagonists or ACE inhibitors.

ellipsisSentence.text: These interactions should be considered in patients taking NSAIDs including selective COX-2 inhibitors concomitantly with diuretics and angiotensin II antagonists or ACE inhibitors.

sentence.text: It is not known whether chlorothiazide can cause fetal harm when administered to a pregnant woman, however, thiazides cross the placental barrier and appear in cord blood.
